title: Recovery scams (fake ‘we can get your money back’)
summary: After you’ve been scammed, criminals may target you again by promising to recover your money — for an upfront fee.
how_it_works: You’re contacted by someone claiming they can recover stolen funds.
They may impersonate authorities or ‘recovery agents’.
They demand fees, deposits, or personal data — then vanish.
warning_signs: Claims of special access or guaranteed recovery.
Pressure to act quickly and keep it secret.
example_hooks: “We traced your funds—pay a fee to release them.”
what_to_do: Be skeptical of unsolicited recovery offers.
Only use official channels (bank, police, Scamwatch guidance).
Don’t pay extra money to recover money.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
